newsitem.title: HUNGARY: HUNGARIAN CAR FIRM IS LATEST BOMBING TARGET.
newsitem.headline: HUNGARIAN CAR FIRM IS LATEST BOMBING TARGET.

text.p: Hand grenades damaged several cars at a dealership in the Hungarian capital Budapest as a gangland war continued unchecked, police said on Tuesday.
They said witnesses saw one or two men running away after the attack on Monday night.

No one was injured, but police said at least one or two hand grenades had not exploded and they closed the road outside the car firm to conduct a search. A forensics team searched the lot shortly after 8 a.m. but appeared to find nothing.
Residents of the city of two million people are becoming alarmed by the rash of hand grenade attacks, petrol bombings and shootings which has escalated since it began in September
Police have admitted receiving little cooperation from victims.
The owner of the car dealership, interviewed by reporters, declined to give his name and added, "I don't know anything about this."
State radio quoted the new national police chief, Attila Bertha, as saying he expected there to be more bombings "because this is a mafia war associated with the development of society".

The attacks have mostly been aimed at restaurants, night clubs and car dealerships, usually after closing hours, but last Friday the wife and daughter of a Chinese restaurant owner were killed by a hand grenade left in the restaurant's toilet.
"What can I say? I could be the next one," said Andras Donko, owner of a auto repair garage opposite the car dealership.

On Monday morning, firefighters were called out to extinguish a blaze started by petrol bombs lobbed into the garden of a Greek restaurant. The firemen removed gas canisters which officials said could have caused a major explosion.
So far, the crime wave has had no effect on Hungary's vital tourist industry, but diplomats said the government is becoming increasingly worried.
"This has become a really high priority for the government," a diplomat said. "They are putting a lot of effort into it."
"But it's an uphill battle," the diplomat said. "There's so much money floating around."
